thread.title: Quick strikes from younger players boost Elon women in CAA soccer victory
thread.title_full: Quick strikes from younger players boost Elon women in CAA soccer victory

author: Alex Simon Times-News correspondent
title: Quick strikes from younger players boost Elon women in CAA soccer victory
text: Posted Oct. 12, 2015 at 12:07 AM Updated at 12:08 AM ELON — On Senior Day at Rudd Field, it was the youngsters who shined in Elon’s 2-0 victory against College of Charleston in Colonial Athletic Association women’s soccer Sunday afternoon. Sophomore Susannah Anderson and freshman Tori Baliatico scored within three minutes of each other, giving the Phoenix its first conference victory. Neither Anderson nor Baliatico started on the hot afternoon, something that coach Chris Neal made note of. “We were really able to go deep off our bench,” he said. “On a hot day like (this), with a Sunday grind less than 48 hours after Friday night’s game — I was really impressed with how the substitutes played in the second half.” After 80 minutes of balanced play without much to note, Elon (9-3-2 overall, 1-2-1 CAA) secured a corner kick opportunity. Amanda Lasater booted a perfect cross in to Anderson, who headed it past the wall of Cougars (8-7, 2-4) to give the Phoenix its first goal. Just two minutes later, Baliatico sprinted under a long ball and had a beautiful touch past Cougar goalkeeper Genevieve Henderson, slotting her shot into the empty net to finish the spurt for Elon. “I get nervous whenever I get in these situations,” Baliatico said. “I don’t want to miss the ball or the goal. When I kicked it, at first I thought, ‘Wow, I kicked it too hard, it’s going to hit the crossbar or go over.’ But once it went in, I got up and celebrated.” Neal reiterated that he has been telling Baliatico to use her athleticism to make an impact. “But with her level of speed — that’s a kid that finished top-10 in the country in 400-meter hurdles coming out of high school — if she’s aggressive and reads the play a little bit, she gets the jump on players, she can use her pace and athleticism to do a lot of damage,” Neal said. “That was electric, that goal.” By Alex Simon
